issue.title: (Logic of) LocalRequestDispatcher lost when upgrading to 2.0.0-M4
issue.body:
In https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/pull/609 I was asked for feedback on how the migration to 2.0.0-M4 went. I spent quite a bit debugging the WildFly container, and here is what I found so far:

In the pre-2.0 world, the `org.jolokia.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.backend.LocalRequestDispatcher` by default.
The LocalRequestDispatcher handles my JmxSearchRequest.

After upgrading to 2.2.0-M4, the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.RequestDispatcherImpl`. This by default has exactly one RequestHandler: `org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.VersionRequestHandler`. Therefore I get a 
`java.lang.IllegalStateException: Internal error: No request handler found for handling JmxSearchRequest[objectName = *:*]`.

For reference: [JmxAgentServlet.java.txt](https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/files/13070830/JmxAgentServlet.java.txt) is my agent servlet.

Any advice how to get the _old request handling logic_ back would be greatly appreciated!

comment.body:
BTW, I was just helping with similar problem - but with Spring Boot and Spring Boot Admin: perspilling/sba-example#1

`No service of type interface org.jolokia.server.core.service.serializer.Serializer` means you miss `org.jolokia:jolokia-service-serializer:2.0.0-M4` jar on your classpath.

issue.title: (Logic of) LocalRequestDispatcher lost when upgrading to 2.0.0-M4
issue.body:
In https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/pull/609 I was asked for feedback on how the migration to 2.0.0-M4 went. I spent quite a bit debugging the WildFly container, and here is what I found so far:

In the pre-2.0 world, the `org.jolokia.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.backend.LocalRequestDispatcher` by default.
The LocalRequestDispatcher handles my JmxSearchRequest.

After upgrading to 2.2.0-M4, the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.RequestDispatcherImpl`. This by default has exactly one RequestHandler: `org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.VersionRequestHandler`. Therefore I get a 
`java.lang.IllegalStateException: Internal error: No request handler found for handling JmxSearchRequest[objectName = *:*]`.

For reference: [JmxAgentServlet.java.txt](https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/files/13070830/JmxAgentServlet.java.txt) is my agent servlet.

Any advice how to get the _old request handling logic_ back would be greatly appreciated!

comment.body:
> Looking forward for your feedback then. What do you mean by "not render correctly" - is it about processing JSONs from Jolokia at client (browser) side?

Yes, that was my suspicion: that the JSON sent to the client looks a bit different.

**But** - after successfully having created the result in `BackendManager` - a few lines later I get an `IllegalStateException` (feeling very stupid now):
```
java.lang.IllegalStateException: No service of type interface org.jolokia.server.core.service.serializer.Serializer found
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.JolokiaContextImpl.getMandatoryService(JolokiaContextImpl.java:82)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager.callRequestDispatcher(BackendManager.java:171)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager.handleRequest(BackendManager.java:93)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.http.HttpRequestHandler.executeRequest(HttpRequestHandler.java:198)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.http.HttpRequestHandler.handleGetRequest(HttpRequestHandler.java:81)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.http.AgentServlet$2.handleRequest(AgentServlet.java:515)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.http.AgentServlet.handleSecurely(AgentServlet.java:384)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.http.AgentServlet.handle(AgentServlet.java:335)
	at deployment.BisonProcess.ear.CH.obj.webapp.war//org.jolokia.server.core.http.AgentServlet.doGet(AgentServlet.java:288)
```

So my next question is: 
How do I register a serialization service? 
(`json-simple-1.1.1.jar` is on the classpath)

commits.message: Manage Jolokia Agent and Protocol version in filtered properties. Use semverLite in QUnit tests

issue.title: (Logic of) LocalRequestDispatcher lost when upgrading to 2.0.0-M4
issue.body:
In https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/pull/609 I was asked for feedback on how the migration to 2.0.0-M4 went. I spent quite a bit debugging the WildFly container, and here is what I found so far:

In the pre-2.0 world, the `org.jolokia.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.backend.LocalRequestDispatcher` by default.
The LocalRequestDispatcher handles my JmxSearchRequest.

After upgrading to 2.2.0-M4, the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.RequestDispatcherImpl`. This by default has exactly one RequestHandler: `org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.VersionRequestHandler`. Therefore I get a 
`java.lang.IllegalStateException: Internal error: No request handler found for handling JmxSearchRequest[objectName = *:*]`.

For reference: [JmxAgentServlet.java.txt](https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/files/13070830/JmxAgentServlet.java.txt) is my agent servlet.

Any advice how to get the _old request handling logic_ back would be greatly appreciated!

comment.body:
Looking forward for your feedback then.
What do you mean by "not render correctly" - is it about processing JSONs from Jolokia at client (browser) side?

issue.title: (Logic of) LocalRequestDispatcher lost when upgrading to 2.0.0-M4
issue.body:
In https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/pull/609 I was asked for feedback on how the migration to 2.0.0-M4 went. I spent quite a bit debugging the WildFly container, and here is what I found so far:

In the pre-2.0 world, the `org.jolokia.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.backend.LocalRequestDispatcher` by default.
The LocalRequestDispatcher handles my JmxSearchRequest.

After upgrading to 2.2.0-M4, the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.RequestDispatcherImpl`. This by default has exactly one RequestHandler: `org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.VersionRequestHandler`. Therefore I get a 
`java.lang.IllegalStateException: Internal error: No request handler found for handling JmxSearchRequest[objectName = *:*]`.

For reference: [JmxAgentServlet.java.txt](https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/files/13070830/JmxAgentServlet.java.txt) is my agent servlet.

Any advice how to get the _old request handling logic_ back would be greatly appreciated!

comment.body:
That helped a lot - thank you!

Previously, we only had the following dependency:
```
implementation "org.jolokia:jolokia-server-core:2.0.0-M4"
```

Now I added `jolokia-service-jmx`:
```
implementation "org.jolokia:jolokia-server-core:2.0.0-M4"
runtimeOnly "org.jolokia:jolokia-service-jmx:2.0.0-M4"
```
Having both .jars on the classpath , `RequestDispatcherImpl` now uses `org.jolokia.service.jmx.LocalRequestHandler` as well, and returns a result.

The client still does not render the result correctly. Now I really have to check the client code (what I did not yet).
I'll report back here.

issue.title: (Logic of) LocalRequestDispatcher lost when upgrading to 2.0.0-M4
issue.body:
In https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/pull/609 I was asked for feedback on how the migration to 2.0.0-M4 went. I spent quite a bit debugging the WildFly container, and here is what I found so far:

In the pre-2.0 world, the `org.jolokia.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.backend.LocalRequestDispatcher` by default.
The LocalRequestDispatcher handles my JmxSearchRequest.

After upgrading to 2.2.0-M4, the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.BackendManager` uses the `org.jolokia.server.core.backend.RequestDispatcherImpl`. This by default has exactly one RequestHandler: `org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.VersionRequestHandler`. Therefore I get a 
`java.lang.IllegalStateException: Internal error: No request handler found for handling JmxSearchRequest[objectName = *:*]`.

For reference: [JmxAgentServlet.java.txt](https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/files/13070830/JmxAgentServlet.java.txt) is my agent servlet.

Any advice how to get the _old request handling logic_ back would be greatly appreciated!

comment.body:
`org.jolokia.server.core.backend.RequestDispatcherImpl` now delegates request processing to `org.jolokia.server.core.service.request.RequestHandler` and indeed - `org.jolokia.server.core.service.impl.VersionRequestHandler` is available from `jolokia-server-core`.

To get other request handlers - and you want `org.jolokia.service.jmx.LocalRequestHandler`, you need `jolokia-service-jmx` on the classpath as well. Please check if you have it (the error suggest you don't).

issue.title: Sketch how to upgrade main to JakartaEE 10
issue.body:
This pull request sketches what would need to be done to upgrade the `main` branch to Jakarta EE 10.

Open issues:

1. The OSGI modules are commented out, because I was not able to prevent `javax.servlet` from leaking in
(no matter how hard I tried)
2. The two naming tests in `J4pReadIntegrationTest` are disabled.

Apart from these, `mvn package` succeeds, when running with Java 17.

comment.body: @grgrzybek @tadayosi In the meantime - after some time of debugging - I found out that my jmx request is not handled at all on the server side. Please find the details in https://github.com/jolokia/jolokia/issues/612. I must be missing something obvious...

issue.title: Sketch how to upgrade main to JakartaEE 10
issue.body:
This pull request sketches what would need to be done to upgrade the `main` branch to Jakarta EE 10.

Open issues:

1. The OSGI modules are commented out, because I was not able to prevent `javax.servlet` from leaking in
(no matter how hard I tried)
2. The two naming tests in `J4pReadIntegrationTest` are disabled.

Apart from these, `mvn package` succeeds, when running with Java 17.

comment.body:
> The WildFly container starts well and seems to work, but the client shows no results. I have to investigate further with my colleague who better understands the client's request/response handling.

Thanks. Please feel free to file it as a new issue and we can look into it.

issue.title: Sketch how to upgrade main to JakartaEE 10
issue.body:
This pull request sketches what would need to be done to upgrade the `main` branch to Jakarta EE 10.

Open issues:

1. The OSGI modules are commented out, because I was not able to prevent `javax.servlet` from leaking in
(no matter how hard I tried)
2. The two naming tests in `J4pReadIntegrationTest` are disabled.

Apart from these, `mvn package` succeeds, when running with Java 17.

comment.body:
@ohumbel 
> I have to investigate further with my colleague who better understands the client's request/response handling.

Yes, please share as much as you can - it'd really help without our effort to release Jolokia 2.0. The more issues we fix before the release, the better ;)
We are working hard on making this huge release smooth.

issue.title: Sketch how to upgrade main to JakartaEE 10
issue.body:
This pull request sketches what would need to be done to upgrade the `main` branch to Jakarta EE 10.

Open issues:

1. The OSGI modules are commented out, because I was not able to prevent `javax.servlet` from leaking in
(no matter how hard I tried)
2. The two naming tests in `J4pReadIntegrationTest` are disabled.

Apart from these, `mvn package` succeeds, when running with Java 17.

comment.body:
> @ohumbel Thanks for your feedback! Glad that the 2.0 branch works for you. You might have been already using it, but just in case there is already `2.0.0-M4` version available on Maven Central which is a build from the latest 2.0 branch. It is intended for early access like this, so it's very welcome to try it and we'd really like to hear your early feedback.

@tadayosi Frankly I did not integrate the 2.0 branch into our application yet. But in the meantime I integrated the 2.0.0-M4 version. I had to change the artefact name in `build.gradle`, change the import statements (roughly from `org.jolokia` to `org.jolokia.server.core`) and add the new `LogHandler` parameter to the `createRestrictor()` method. 
The WildFly container starts well and seems to work, but the client shows no results.
I have to investigate further with my colleague who better understands the client's request/response handling.
